posts.cooked:
I picked up a couple of Thrifty Novas to test out over the summer.  My hope was to use them with a lower cost mini swerve bot (Nerd Swerve).  I got ahead of myself and tried them with YAGSL and struggled, but it’s my first attempt at a lot of this.  There was very erratic motor behavior.  So I got down to basics and am now only figuring out how to get the PIDs alone to work.

Using a simple program, I’ve just been trying to get one Nova running a Neo at a specified velocity.  With just P, its all jerky but does get up to maintain a speed (less than setpoint).  If I add some FF, I can get it to start more reliably and get closer to setpoint.  I added some I in and it doesn’t seem to accumulate, or it gets erratic.  At this point, I’m just trying to spin the Neo under no load to maintain a speed.

Really, I’m Just wondering if people have used the closed loop PIDs on the Nova. Can’t find much info on them yet.  Only a couple teams said they work and there were few details.

@Sam_Dare FYI there are a few errors in the example code on the website.

For reference, here is the controller setup. In the rest of the code, I’m just running at velocity “400” (ticks/second?) with a button, or running it up and down with a joystick without a PID .  Max Output and Current intentionally set low so I don’t destroy something.

posts.name: Sam Dare
posts.cooked:
Sorry you’re having trouble! Can you shoot us an email at contact@thethriftybot.com with a link to your code and any documentation issues you found? We will get you taken care of.

I know quite a few teams that used the position PID last year on the robot, and I know we have an internal verification of the velocity loop, but I’ll get you plugged in with our guys to see what’s going on. YAGSL support is very much ongoing, and we are working on our own swerve generator we may be able to give you access to for some additional testing. One of the current known pain points is the units not being in native rotations, which makes the PID values more confusing than we would like, so we are working to solve that.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: I can’t confirm how much has changed over the last 6 months or so, but this video exists for Thirty Nova.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure how the Nova deals with the noisy velocity signal from the NEO, but if it’s using substantial filtering like the SparkMAX, using feedback to control velocity of an unloaded NEO will be impossible.  The stable proportional gain in a SparkMAX for velocity of an unloaded NEO is miniscule and will leave huge setpoint offset.  Adding integral just makes the instability caused by the effective delay from all the filtering worse.

Adding inertial load of a heavy flywheel for a shooter or the mass of a robot for swerve velocity control will slow down the velocity loop dynamics such that the controller filtering no longer dominates the dynamics and velocity control with a NEO starts to become feasible.  However, you should still be looking to get the vast majority of your velocity control from feedforward so the feedback can be gentle and not throw the loop into instability trying to closely track a setpoint.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: Note that the video only shows position control using an external encoder.  This works great.  Velocity control using the internal encoder on a unloaded NEO is an entirely different beast.

Thank you all for the info.  Since the Neo is unloaded, I’ll stop fighting velocity for now until I get some kind of load on it.  Currently the swerve module is just on my desk and not mounted to anything.

I’ll move onto the position PID with an external encoder and see if I can get that to work, since that is known to work.

I’ll follow up with @Sam_Dare with any code and also the errors I found on the website in a few days.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
TomT:

I’ll move onto the position PID with an external encoder and see if I can get that to work, since that is known to work.

Position PID with the NEO internal encoder is also likely to work.  If it’s easier for you to experiment with the internal encoder, you may want to try that first.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
Hey @TomT , I’ve been working on YAGSL Nova support on and off again for a while, trying to nail it down. It’s been a low priority project, for me. I put together a full Nova Swerve bot this summer to work with. I think the existing code is not in a working state and I do have a PR into YAGSL for some improvements. Figuring out the internal PID -controller behavior and distance to encoder ticks conversion logic has been the sticking point and I think the current code made an incorrect assumption about whether the factor was in output-units/rotation or rotations/output-unit (the former is correct, not latter). I also found out from Thrifty that there’s an undocumented setVelocity function that takes both the velocity setpoint and the feedforward as a voltage and I finally tried it out last night. If you’d like, you can check out my updates here . Specifically, this file , though the new API call isn’t there yet.

Other issues I’m working on are, 1. No velocity output from the Novas, 2. tuning the PID (well just P) for drive. I’m using kP=0.0005 for angle and kP=0.0003 for drive, which seems OK, but I think I’m seeing the unloaded drive motor problem described above, though there may still be other issues in addition.

Let me know if you’d like to collaborate on this. Thanks!

BlueEpiphone:

Let me know if you’d like to collaborate on this. Thanks!

Definitely keep me posted.  Also, I’m using a CTRE SRX Absolute encoder for steer.  It appears to read correctly from the config software.

I think one would need to set both ThriftyNova.ExternalEncoder and ThriftyNova.EncoderType, but I’m not seeing that anywhere in YAGSL .  Although if it was set through the config manually, I would guess that would stick.  It seemed to.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
I haven’t been able to test a lot of different encoder configs. The ThriftyNovaEncoderSwerve class just sets the encoder type to ABS. So, yeah for now it would need to be manual. I can build that functionality in once the current PR is accepted.

I have Thrifty ABS encoders running analog through the RIO, so I just use ‘thrifty’ as the encoder type, which defaults to the analog implementation.

I do have an update in my repo that did make things work a bit better. I’m still trying to dial in the PID values a bit, I went a factor of 10 lower than before. KP=0.00001.

Quick Summary/Update:

My velocity PID woes are likely due to an unloaded Neo.  Seems like people have used that, so I will test more once I have a robot I can put on the floor.

Moving onto position, I suspect something is amiss when using an external absoluted encoder with PID - maybe the CTRE SRX specifically. I followed the video that @Skyehawk posted (Thank You), but even if P is really small as soon as it gets to setpoint it oscillates violently.

I’ve sent an email to Thrifty Bot as @Sam_Dare requested with details and other comments on the documentation.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: I’ve updated the YAGSL ThriftyNova code so that it accepts different config values for different types of external encoders. You can try it out against my repository . So you can now use, thrifty_nova_rev, thrifty_nova_redux, or thrifty_nova_srx_mag as the encoder type and it should set the external encoder for you when it creates the encoder class. If you have a chance to try it out, let me know if there are any issues. Thanks!

link_counts.title: Set ThriftyNova External Encoder type from config file choice by clrozeboom · Pull Request #349 · BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example · GitHub

posts.cooked:
Just to chime in here @TomT I do not intend on releasing any new versions of YAGSL until i finish my refractor of it in mid Oct-Decmber. However i will continue accepting PR’s like the amazing ones from @BlueEpiphone . So until then you will unfortunately have to use YAGSL from source.

I apologize if this isn’t what you wanted to hear, but the refractor will improve many issues with YAGSL make the code more readable, modular, and hopefully resolve some instability. In 2027 I plan on migrating YAGSL to use my new mech lib to further improve stability and make it even more feature rich!

BlueEpiphone:

I’ve updated the YAGSL ThriftyNova code so that it accepts different config values for different types of external encoders.

Fantastic.  I’ll try it out and let you know

nstrike:

So until then you will unfortunately have to use YAGSL from source.

No problem at all.  I’m just glad people put in the time and effort to make great projects like this happen.

Since my last post, I tried doing a software PID for position since I was having problems with the hardware PID .  It seemed to work as expected.  I’ll nudge @Sam_Dare and Thrify Bot via email to help figure out if I am seeing a hardware PID issue or not.

Here is my test code and the main issue I sent to Thrifty Bot.

The left stick will control the speed of the drive motor in percent, unless A is pressed - then it runs the PID at a fixed setpoint.  This runs fine on the unloaded Neo with only feed forward.

The right stick will control the position (moving the stick from up to down should rotate it 360 degrees).  Pressing B make is spin at a fixed percentage as a sanity check.

With the steer P set very low, I can feel it moving the motor in the right direction to hit the setpoint.  When it hits the setpoint, it oscillates pretty violently.  If I move the joystick, the setpoint does change as well.  This is the same behavior I saw when running it via Thrifty Config.

I suspect the internal distance to setpoint is (or isn’t) wrapping around properly, causing the significant oscillation. (yellow on the graph).  This behavior happens with or without “Absolute Encoder Wrapping” on or off.

Screenshot 2025-08-07 192902 2783×1120 228 KB

Screenshot 2025-08-07 192902 2783×1120 228 KB

Screenshot 2025-08-07 192902 2783×1120 228 KB

lol.  Just solved my own problem.  After I posted, I noticed the current increased as it approached the setpoint.  I tried inverting the motor in Thrifty Config, and that did not help.  So I tried a negative P value, and now it behaves as I would expect.
